messages.text: What is the output of `julia> DEPOT_PATH` ?

`julia> ENV["DEPOT_PATH"]` sets an environment variable named `DEPOT_PATH`.  It does not do anything to Julia's `DEPOT_PATH` (constant) variable.  If anything, you would want to modify `ENV["JULIA_DEPOT_PATH"]`, but I suspect that won't do what you want because Julia probably only reads it at startup when initializing the contents of the `DEPOT_PATH` constant.

messages.text:
Suppose that I have the following string: `"=0.1.0, =0.1.1, =0.1.2, =0.2.0, =0.2.1, =0.2.2"`

Obviously this is a `[compat]` entry. Using the hyphen range syntax, we can rewrite this `[compat]` entry as the following string: `"0.1.0 - 0.1.2, 0.2.0 - 0.2.2"`

We can see that these two are equivalent:
```julia> foo = "=0.1.0, =0.1.1, =0.1.2, =0.2.0, =0.2.1, =0.2.2"
"=0.1.0, =0.1.1, =0.1.2, =0.2.0, =0.2.1, =0.2.2"

julia> bar = "0.1.0 - 0.1.2, 0.2.0 - 0.2.2"
"0.1.0 - 0.1.2, 0.2.0 - 0.2.2"

julia> Pkg.Types.semver_spec(foo) == Pkg.Types.semver_spec(bar)
true```
Is there a programmatic way to convert `foo` to `bar`. In other words, is there a function in Pkg that would take in `foo` (as a string) and return `bar` (as a string)?

messages.text:
I have a question. Suppose my global environment in `~/.julia/environments/v1.6/Project.toml`contains just IJulia and Pluto. Then I run a Pluto notebook that does
```Pkg.activate(mktempdir())
	Pkg.add([
			Pkg.PackageSpec(name="PlutoUI",version="0.7"),
			Pkg.PackageSpec(name="Plots"),

			])

	using PlutoUI, Plots```
This takes some relatively large time t1, because Plots. If I totally close the notebook, and then open it again, which takes time t2, is t2 < t1 because Plots was already installed once and some of that was cached, or is t1==t2 because all of that was installed to the tempdir only?
I’d try testing this, but as I’ve already had Plots installed, it might not be a good test.

This takes some relatively large time t1, because Plots. If I totally close the notebook, and then open it again, which takes time t2, is t2 < t1 because Plots was already installed once and some of that was cached, or is t1==t2 because all of that was installed to the tempdir only?
I’d try testing this, but as I’ve already had Plots installed, it might not be a good test.

messages.text:
Just a question about order of how packages are pulled. I am currently working through a package that provides its own Manifest and Project files. Some of the packages are not up to date, and I do not want to update them because of reproducibility.

However, as I work through them I'd like to use `Gnuplot` to plot some data. When I do `add Gnuplot`  in the package environment, it seems to update all of the dependencies. My workaround right now is to install the latest version of Gnuplot in the global `v1.6` environment, and so when `using Gnuplot`  even if the package env is activated, would pull the package in from the `v1.6` env.

But this seems hacky. Is there a more systematic way of doing it?

elements.text:

But this seems hacky. Is there a more systematic way of doing it?

messages.text: Use `]add Gnuplot --preserve=all`: <https://pkgdocs.julialang.org/v1/repl/#repl-add|https://pkgdocs.julialang.org/v1/repl/#repl-add>
Thanks

Does it not work with `dev`?
```(COVID_model) pkg> dev Gnuplot --preserve=all
ERROR: Unable to parse `--preserve=all` as a package.```

messages.text:
I saw that in v1.6 of Pkg `] generate` is deprecated. Am I the only one who heavily uses this feature? :thinking_face:

I was looking through the code to see how easy it would be to change `generate` to handle names that end in “.jl” (rather than give the error “not a valid package name”), and I was surprised to see that it’s deprecated.

PkgTemplates is great of course, but it’s a bit heavy weight, sometimes you just want to create a completely minimal package…

elements.text: I saw that in v1.6 of Pkg
is deprecated. Am I the only one who heavily uses this feature?
I was looking through the code to see how easy it would be to change

to handle names that end in “.jl” (rather than give the error “not a valid package name”), and I was surprised to see that it’s deprecated.

PkgTemplates is great of course, but it’s a bit heavy weight, sometimes you just want to create a completely minimal package…
